Writing a Task on PyCubed¶

All the operations performed by the cubesat via the PyCubed board, are in the form of tasks. A task file is written, and pasted in the Tasks directory on the PYCUBED drive.

Understanding the Task File Structure¶

The task file consists of the Task object that encapsulates the function to be performed.

class task.Task(satellite)¶

The Task Object.

priority¶

The priority level assigned to the task.

Type

int

frequency¶

Number of times the task must be executed in 1 second (Hz).

Type

float

task_id¶

User defined task identifier.

Type

int

__init__(satellite)¶

Initialise the Task by registering the cubesat object on it. This is required to access the functionalities offered by the PyCubed board.

Parameters

satellite (Satellite) – The cubesat to be registered

coroutine main_task(*args, **kwargs)¶

Contains the code for the user defined task.

Parameters

  • *args – Variable number of arguments used for task execution.

  • **kwargs – Variable number of keyword arguments used for task execution.

Note

The method main_task is NOT a regular function. It is a coroutine. Execution of coroutines does not take place in the same manner as execution of regular functions. While the scheduler in code.py abstracts the complexities of coroutines from the user, it may be a good idea to explore the basics of the same, through this link.

Warning

The class in the task files MUST be named Task while the main async method/coroutine to be scheduled MUST be named main_task. This is due to the way the files are imported and scheduled in code.py. Not adhering to the template will result in errors.

On boot-up, the code.py script imports all these tasks and schedules them based on the specifications provided in the tasks.

Steps to execute Tasks on PyCubed¶

  1. Follow the template mentioned in Understanding the Task File Structure to write the task file.

  2. Paste the task file in the Tasks folder.

  3. Reset or reboot the board.

The task file is automatically imported upon boot, leading to its execution at the specified frequency, with the specified priority level.

A Simple Example¶

The example below demonstrates the simple task of sending the message “Hello World!” through the radio at a frequency of 1 Hz.

# Task to send "Hello World" on the radio at a frequency of 1Hz

class Task:
        def __init__(self, satellite):
                self.cubesat = satellite

        async def main_task(self):
                print("Sending message from PyCubed....")
                self.cubesat.radio2.send("Hello World!", keep_listening=True)
                print("Message sent from PyCubed")

        priority = 1
        frequency = 1
        task_id = 4

The above example sets the priority of the task to 1, sets the task ID to 4, and sets the execution rate of the task to 1 Hz.

To run this example, create a task file (can be named anything, for example: radio_send_task.py), and copy the code onto that file. Paste this file in the Tasks folder on PYCUBED, and then reset the board using Ctrl+D. The task will automatically be executed, at the specified frequency.

Stopping Tasks on PyCubed¶

In certain situations, some tasks may have to be stopped from within another task.

For example: If we want to end all tasks upon receiving a “killswitch” command on the radio.

For this purpose a StopTask object is used, which resides in the stop_tasks.py script.

class stop_tasks.StopTask(satellite, num_of_tasks, task_ids)¶

The StopTask object that is used to stop tasks from within a task.

__init__(satellite, num_of_tasks, task_ids)¶

Initialise the StopTask object by regsitering the cubesat on it. This is required to access the list of scheduled task objects from which the appropriate tasks are stopped.

Parameters

  • satellite (Satellite) – The cubesat to be registered

  • num_of_tasks (int) – The number of tasks to be stopped

  • task_ids (list of int) – A list containing the integer task_ids of the tasks to be stopped

stop()¶

Object method that is used to stop the tasks specified by the parameters provided during initialisation.

An example is provided here- task file to listen for messages.

Warning

Do not forget to import the StopTask object from the stop_tasks.py module when using this functionality.
